root.pub-comments: The author refers to the Sino-Caucasian family is as a macrophylum (Bengtson 1991:67). “Sino-Caucasian languages (Basque, North-Caucasian, Sumerian, Burushaski, Sino-Tibetan, Yeniseian, and Na-Dene) are members of a macrophylum-level of grouping, based mainly on lexical isoglosses […], but also on some structural analogies […]. Starostin on the basis of NC [North-Caucasian], ST [Sino-Tibetan], and Yen [Yenisean], dates Sino-Caucasian to the 8th or 9th millennium B.C. (1989:43). With Na-Dene factored in, the date would be somewhat earlier” (Bengtson 1991:70).
root.publications: Bengtson, John D. 1991. Notes on Sino-Caucasian, Dene-Sino-Caucasian Languages. Materials from the First International Interdisciplinary Symposium on Language and Prehistory, Ann Arbor, 8-12 November, 1988. , Bochum Publications in Evolutionary Cultural Semiotics, vol. 32, 67-129. Bochum: Bochumer Universitätsverlag. ISBN 3934453554, 9783934453555

child.pub-comments: Node not named by the author. Bengston doesn't specify that North Caucasian and Sumerian consitute one group in the main claffisication on p. 67 (Bengston 1991:67), however in his following discussion on p. 79, he tentatively includes North-Caucasian and Sumerian into one subgroup: “Such a phylum subordinate [like Basque-Burushaski, see Basque-Burushaski node] to Sino-Caucasian might also include North Caucasian and (Sumerian?), and would approximate Shevoroshkin's western Sino-Caucasian [icludes Basque-North Caucasian-Hatti-Hurri-Urartean]” (Bengtson 1991:79).
child.publications: Bengtson, John D. 1991. Notes on Sino-Caucasian, Dene-Sino-Caucasian Languages. Materials from the First International Interdisciplinary Symposium on Language and Prehistory, Ann Arbor, 8-12 November, 1988. , Bochum Publications in Evolutionary Cultural Semiotics, vol. 32, 67-129. Bochum: Bochumer Universitätsverlag. ISBN 3934453554, 9783934453555

child.pub-comments: The author claims that Gutian might possibly belong to the North-Caucasian language family: “North-Caucasian (including the extinct Hatti, Hurrian, Urartean, and possibly Gutian” (Bengtson 1991:67).

child.pub-comments: Node not named by the author. Bengston doesn't specify that Basque and Burushaski consitute one group in the main claffisication on p. 67 (Bengston 1991:67), however in his following discussion on p. 79, he states that they belong to the same phylum: “[...] the relationship between Basque and Burushaski is closer than that of the coordinate members (phyla) is a macrophylum. The close correspondence in morphology are rather characteristic of two members of families belonging to the same phylum (e.g., such as Albanian and Armenian within IE [Indo-European])” (Bengtson 1991:79).
child.publications: Bengtson, John D. 1991. Notes on Sino-Caucasian, Dene-Sino-Caucasian Languages. Bochum: Bochumer Universitätsverlag. ISBN 3934453554, 9783934453555

child.pub-comments: The author claims that ancient Iberian might possibly belong to the Sino-Caucasian macrophylum: “Basque (and possible ancient Iberian)” (Bengtson 1991:67).
